Template:

I am handing off; no further actions from my side tonight.

message:
Hi all — apology for my earlier note where I referenced INC-2187 without context. That caused confusion and some duplicate troubleshooting.

INC-2187 = intermittent loss of telemetry from vessel KD-AUV-07 while alongside Dock 4 (Rotterdam), first observed 2026-02-03 14:12 CET.

Current status
- Mitigation: telemetry stream stable since 2026-02-03 16:40 CET after modem reboot + antenna connector reseat
- Root cause: still under investigation (likely RF interference vs. connector degradation)

Owners / next steps
- Engineering (@NilsJ): review modem logs + firmware (link: https://kestreldock.atlassian.net/browse/INC-2187)
- Port Ops (@SanneP): keep KD-AUV-07 on increased monitoring at Dock 4 through 2026-02-04 18:00 CET; escalate to on-call if signal drops >2 min (runbook: https://confluence.kestreldock/runbooks/telemetry-drop)

If you were already investigating this in parallel, please add notes directly to the incident ticket so we keep one source of truth. Thanks, Marieke
context: Marieke previously referenced 'INC-2187' in a cross-team thread without explaining it, leading to confusion and duplicate troubleshooting. She follows up to apologize and provide a concise summary plus links and owners.

message:
@Claudine Berset @Jonas Meier — I saw the mandatory VDI patch window overlaps with the cat model run I planned for UW.

To stay compliant (no local exports/screenshots), can we align on one of these options?
- Option A: I start the run before the window and let it continue unattended on VDI (if sessions won’t be terminated).
- Option B: IT provides a temporary exception/alternative VDI host for the run during the window.
- Option C: I shift the run to the first slot after the window; I can deliver results by EOD tomorrow.

message:
@Nkechi Okafor-Mills thank you for the suggestion about adding an extra vitals re-check for all chronic disease follow-ups. I wanted to share a quick concern from room flow.

On days when we are short-staffed, doing a full re-check for every follow-up tends to slow turnover (we can end up with patients waiting for rooms even when providers are ready).

Would you be open to a narrower trigger instead? For example:
- Re-check vitals if the first set is out of range, patient reports new/worsening symptoms, med changes were made today, or the visit runs >20–30 min.
- Otherwise keep the initial set only.

This seems to help catch the cases where it matters (e.g., BP high on arrival or patient feels dizzy) without bottlenecking routine stable follow-ups. If you agree, I can align with the MAs on shift and we can trial it for a week and review.
context: A care coordinator suggested adding an extra vitals re-check for every chronic disease follow-up, but Jinwoo has seen it slow down room turnover when staffing is thin. He wants to disagree respectfully and propose a narrower trigger.

message:
@Priya Malhotra-Singh

Following the near-miss with privileged notes last week, I’ve put together a short Slack-to-folder checklist so we’re consistently saving/filing anything that comes in via Slack before it goes near a draft.

From today, please use this each time you’re moving docs/notes from Slack into the matter folder:
1) Save to the correct matter: Client > Matter no. > 01 Correspondence / 03 Advice (as appropriate)
2) Rename using: YYYY-MM-DD – Source (Slack) – short description
3) If it’s privileged/sensitive, put it in the “Privileged” subfolder and add “PRIV” to the filename
4) If unsure where it belongs, park in “00 Triage” and tag me (or the matter lead)

Template lives here: Knowledge Base > Templates > “Slack-to-folder checklist” (link pinned in #ops).

No blame intended — just trying to make the safe way the easy way. Let me know if you want me to sanity-check the first couple on your matters.
context: After a near-miss with misfiled privileged notes, Gareth has created a simple repeatable Slack-to-folder checklist and wants the team to adopt it. He announces the change with concise instructions, rationale, and where the template lives.

message: Eduardo hi—I'm at Kathonzweni borehole now and it just stopped pumping kabisa during school water collection time. Headteacher is texting me pics of watoto queuing and people are getting anxious, you know how it becomes when everyone is watching and asking “kuna nini?” I checked around the pump house and the switch area, it was working earlier then suddenly nothing, and county water office is calling me asking if it’s mechanical or power issue before they send anyone. I’m trying to calm the crowd and the mwalimu mkuu is worried because lunch prep is stuck. I don’t want to say wrong thing to county, but right now it’s not responding when we try again, maybe power is off? but also could be pump jam, I can’t confirm. Network is weak so I may miss calls, just wanted you to know what is happening and I’m here with them as we wait.
expected_rephrase:
Eduardo — urgent update from Kathonzweni borehole (at pump house now).

Situation: Borehole stopped pumping suddenly during school water collection hour; headteacher is sending photos of children queuing. Community + school are anxious and asking for immediate help.

Quick checks I’ve done on-site: 
- Tried restarting at switch area — still no pumping
- Visual check around pump house — nothing obvious (no clear sign yet if mechanical vs power)

What I need from you: Please advise what you want me to tell County Water Office right now, and whether I should request they dispatch a technician immediately (they are asking me to confirm “mechanical or power” before they move).

Constraints: Low network here, I may miss calls; best is WhatsApp/SMS. I’ll stay with the crowd and keep things calm as we wait.

message: Hi Eduardo, nimefika on the matatu heading back and network is coming and going so I’ll try send this now. I spent last two days moving around to follow up the attendance issue you raised and also to calm some worries from community since there were those rumours that the sign-in sheets were filled later. In each place I met the chairlady and secretary plus one of the viongozi wa vijana and we sat with the training folder, went through names and also asked a few members to confirm if they were there that day, you can really feel they are tired of being doubted but at same time they understand why we must be careful for donors. One village had the book kept at home of the treasurer because office was locked, and another they had mixed the sheets from different sessions so it looked like same handwriting, but when we talked through it they explained it was the teacher who helped them write because some members can’t write well, and they were a bit defensive at first but later opened up. I didn’t see intentional cooking of data, more like poor process and pressure to show full attendance, lakini I told them we will not punish, we just need clean record and next time they should sign same day and use thumbprint where needed, and I asked them to redo the sheet neatly with date and facilitator present. I’ll share more when I get stable network, but overall I think we can correct the dataset and also do quick refresher with committees so this doesn’t repeat, I’m quite tired but wanted you to know before you continue analysis 🙏🏾
expected_rephrase:
Hi Eduardo — quick update from the matatu (network iko unstable).

Over the last two days I visited **3 villages** to verify the committee training attendance after the rumours about sign-in sheets being filled later (and the inconsistencies you flagged). In each village I met with the **chairlady + secretary** (and in two places also the **kiongozi wa vijana**) and we reviewed the training folder, then asked a few members to confirm attendance.

What I found:
- **No clear evidence of intentional “cooking”** the data. More like weak process + pressure to show full attendance.
- **Village A:** attendance book was kept at the treasurer’s home because the office was locked.
- **Village B:** sheets from different sessions were mixed, so the handwriting looked the same; they said a local teacher helped write for members who can’t write.

Actions agreed with committees:
- Attendance must be signed **same day**; use **thumbprint** where needed.
- They will **redo/clean up the sheets** with correct dates and facilitator present.
- We should do a **short refresher** with committees on record-keeping so this doesn’t repeat.

Next step: when I get stable network I’ll send which names/sessions need correction so you can update the dataset on your side. I’m tired but wanted you to have the headline before you continue analysis.

workspace_type: NGO focused on rural water access & climate resilience
message:
Eduardo hi, I’m on the road back from Kathonzweni and wanted to share something on the GPS + photo for every small repair you asked. I understand why you need it for donors and accountability (and I’m not refusing), but on ground it is becoming hard especially when it’s urgent like pipe joint leaking at night or a tap broken and women are queueing. My fundi and the water committee guys are telling me it slows them down because first we stop, take phone, open location, then pictures, then explain again why we are taking photos, and network is low so uploads fail and they feel we are doing “inspection”. Today the mwenyekiti at Kyandue committee told me straight that constant photos makes them feel we don’t trust them, like serikali audit, and he asked if we think they are lying. I tried to calm it and explain it’s for reporting to partners, si kwa kuwashuku, but you know trust is very sensitive and we have been building relationship slowly since last drought. Also sometimes household members don’t want their faces or homestead in photo, so my team is now taking far pictures and it doesn’t show the repair well, then we get question later.

Maybe we can adjust how strict this is? For the small things (rubber washer, tightening clamp, replacing tap head) can we just log in the repair book + one photo per site per week, and only GPS/photo for bigger work or when it’s new installation? If we keep pushing every time, committees will start refusing or delaying permission and then we look bad also. I’m feeling squeezed between community and donor side honestly. Let me know what you think, I will be in field again tomorrow and want to avoid more complaint 🙏
expected_rephrase:
Eduardo hi — quick field note on the GPS + photo requirement for every minor repair.

What I’m seeing on ground: When we stop to capture GPS + photos for small urgent fixes (leaking joints, broken taps), it slows the fundi/committee work, and with low network the upload fails so we repeat. Some committee members are interpreting frequent photos as “inspection” rather than partnership. Today the mwenyekiti at Kyandue told me it feels like we don’t trust them (like serikali audit). I explained it’s for donor reporting, si kwa kuwashuku, but trust is very sensitive right now. Also some households don’t want faces/homesteads in photos, so the pictures become less useful and still raise questions later.

Ask: Can we agree on a lighter documentation approach for minor repairs?
- Minor repairs (washer, tightening clamp, tap head): record in repair book + share one summary photo per site per week
- Bigger work/new installations: full GPS + photo evidence each time

If you’re okay, I’ll brief the field team tomorrow so we are consistent and reduce irritation with committees. If not, please advise what minimum evidence you need for donors so I can explain it better in community.

message:
@Somchai Kittisak + Faculty Admin Leads — heads up for tomorrow’s data extract: Govt reporting rule update re: *late withdrawal* coding just came through and we need to align how we’re recording these in SMS before the run.

For audit trail, I’m pasting the relevant wording from the guidance (emphasis theirs):
“Where a student withdraws after the census date and the provider determines the withdrawal is due to special circumstances, the withdrawal must be reported using the Late Withdrawal Indicator ‘Y’ and the Withdrawal Reason Code ‘SC’. Where a student withdraws after census date and the provider does not determine special circumstances, the withdrawal must be reported using Late Withdrawal Indicator ‘N’ and the Withdrawal Reason Code ‘LW’. Providers must ensure that the effective date of withdrawal is recorded as the date the student notified the provider, not the date the provider processed the request. For reporting purposes, a provider must not report a withdrawal as ‘Administrative’ where the student has initiated the withdrawal.”

Links for reference:
- Dept guidance PDF: https://intranet.nbp.edu.au/compliance/gov-reporting/2026-late-withdrawal-update
- Our procedure (Records): https://intranet.nbp.edu.au/registrar/procedures/withdrawals#late-withdrawal
- Coding table in SMS: https://sms.nbp.edu.au/lookup/withdrawal-codes
- Form (special circumstances): https://forms.nbp.edu.au/SC-withdrawal

Can everyone please review and update as needed today — also please keep a note somewhere that you’ve seen this (audit liaison asked for written evidence). Sorry, lots of text, but want to make sure we’re covered.
expected_rephrase:
@Somchai Kittisak + Faculty Admin Leads — urgent before tomorrow’s data extract: the government has changed how *late withdrawals* must be coded.

**Plain-language takeaway (what to do today):**
1) **If Special Circumstances is approved** → code the enrolment as **Late Withdrawal Indicator = Y** and **Withdrawal Reason Code = SC**.
2) **If Special Circumstances is not approved** → code as **Late Withdrawal Indicator = N** and **Withdrawal Reason Code = LW**.
3) **Effective withdrawal date** must be **the date the student notified us** (not the date we process it).
4) **Don’t use “Administrative”** if the student initiated the withdrawal.

**Action required by EOD today:**
- Faculty Admin Leads: please check any *post‑census withdrawals currently in progress* in your area and confirm they’re coded per the above (especially anything marked “Administrative” or with an effective date that looks like a processing date).
- Somchai: could you please confirm if Compliance wants a screenshot/export of the updated coding list for audit evidence, or is this Slack notice sufficient?

**References (for anyone who needs the source text):**

message:
@Somchai @IT Service Desk @Learning Systems Analyst — hi all, sorry to jump in like this but we’re seeing what looks like duplicated grades from the LMS batch upload for one unit and lecturers are now reporting mismatched final marks in SRS 😬

Just flagging because of last month’s release incident etc. Per *Academic Results & Grade Management Policy* (section 7.3 “Amendments and Corrections”):

> 7.3.1 Where an error in results publication is identified, the University must take all reasonable steps to correct the error as soon as practicable and ensure an audit trail is maintained.
> 
> 7.3.2 Result amendments must be actioned only on receipt of authorised documentation from the Course Coordinator/Unit Assessor and recorded in the student record with the date/time, reason for change, and authorising officer.
> 
> 7.3.4 System-generated changes must be reported to Registry and IT, and may require an incident report where student impact is confirmed.

Can you please check the batch job logs / last sync run and also advise what we should tell lecturers in the meantime? I’m pulling a list of impacted students but it’s a bit messy because I’m not sure which mark is the “real” one yet. If someone can also confirm whether we should pause any further LMS grade pushes for now that would help.
expected_rephrase:
@Somchai @IT Service Desk @Learning Systems Analyst — urgent: we’re seeing what looks like duplicated grades from the LMS batch upload for one unit, and lecturers are reporting mismatched final marks in SRS. Given leadership scrutiny after last month’s incident, I’d like us to treat this as a priority.

**Plain-language policy takeaway:** until we confirm the source of the change, we should avoid making manual mark edits without authorised documentation, and we need to preserve an audit trail for any corrections.

**Need help with (priority order):**
1) **ASAP (now):** Please confirm whether we should **pause further LMS grade pushes/syncs** to prevent additional changes.
2) **ASAP:** Check the **batch job/sync logs** for the last run (timestamp, unit code, any retries/duplicates) and let us know what you find.
3) **Next (once 1–2 are underway):** Guidance on **what to tell lecturers today** (e.g., acknowledge issue, ask them not to resubmit grades, ETA for next update).

I’m compiling a list of potentially impacted students/records, but I can’t validate which mark is correct until we understand what the sync did. I’ll share the list as soon as it’s in a usable state.

flag_descriptions.Unclear Prioritization During Peaks: Doesn’t indicate which items are urgent vs. can wait, causing queue confusion.

context: A batch upload from the LMS appears to have duplicated grades for one unit, and lecturers are reporting mismatched final marks in the student records system.

To keep it tidy/audit-safe, can you:
1) pull the full enrolment + credit history in SIS (screenshot the credit tab + the re-enrolment event pls)
2) cross-check against the CRM case thread and note which ID each note is under
3) confirm the name/DOB match and whether there’s any merge pending
4) add a short note in both systems linking the two IDs + date/time you checked
5) then forward me the screenshots + your notes so I can attach to the student email + close the loop.

Sorry, a bit process-y 😅 but we’ve had a few of these lately and I don’t want us to miss a compliance thing. Not urgent-urgent, but ideally today if possible.

What I need is just confirmation of: (1) whether the RPL credit is still on the SIS record and if/when it dropped off, and (2) which CRM case/ID the related notes sit under (and whether there’s a merge issue).

message:
@Somchai Kittisak hey — I get wanting to help here, but we can’t manually enrol into a capped unit after the deadline just as a courtesy (even if there was an informal promise at O-Week). Otherwise we end up in “magical exceptions” territory, which never ends well 😅

For reference, here’s the relevant bit from the Enrolment & Variations Procedure (v4.2):

“4.1.2 Enrolment deadlines are published in the Academic Calendar. Requests received after the published deadline will not be processed except where an approved exception applies.
4.1.3 Approved exceptions are limited to: (a) documented system error preventing enrolment during the open period; (b) administrative error by the Institute; (c) approved accessibility adjustment coordinated via Student Support; or (d) other circumstances approved in writing by the Registrar.
4.3.1 Where a unit is capacity capped, enrolment is permitted only up to the approved cap. Manual enrolments that exceed the cap are not permitted.
4.3.2 Staff must not provide assurances of enrolment outside published timelines or caps. Any such assurances do not constitute approval and must be referred to the Registrar’s Office.
4.4.5 All exception requests must be documented in the student record with supporting evidence and approval trail.”

If you think it fits 4.1.3 (e.g., system issue etc), can you send through the details + any emails from orientation and we can log it properly. Otherwise best option is waitlist/alt unit.
expected_rephrase:
@Somchai Kittisak — I understand the intent to help, but we can’t manually enrol the student into a capped unit after the deadline on a courtesy basis, even if something informal was said at orientation.

Plain-language takeaway: after the deadline we can only process late enrolments if there’s a documented exception (e.g., system/admin error, approved accessibility adjustment, or written approval from the Registrar), and we still can’t exceed the unit cap.

If you think one of those exceptions applies, please send me:
- what prevented the student enrolling on time (and any screenshots/timestamps if it was a system issue)
- the orientation email/notes where the promise was made
- the student ID + unit code

I’ll log it and advise next steps. If there isn’t an exception, we’ll need to keep them on the waitlist or look at an alternative unit.

flag_descriptions.Policy Copy-Paste Without Summary: Shares large blocks of policy rather than a short plain-language takeaway.

context: A faculty admin asks to manually enroll a student into a capped unit ‘as a courtesy’ after the deadline, citing an informal promise made during orientation.
Brontë accidentally tagged the wrong student ID in a public operations channel while asking for a record check, and a colleague pointed out the privacy risk.
